titlepage.titleproper: A Guide to the Michael La Vean French documents collection, 1751-1851
titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
Special Collections and Archives C0078
titlepage.author: Eron Ackerman

archdesc.runner: Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University

did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: George Mason University.Special Collections and Archives.

did.unittitle: Michael La Vean French documents collection
did.abstract: The La Vean collection contains 268 documents and books from the period between 1751 and 1851. The majority of the documents come from the years between the creation of the French National Assembly in 1789 and the beginning of the Empire in 1805.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: There are no restrictions on personal use. Permission to publish material from the Michael La Vean French documents collection must be obtained from Special Collections Research Center, George Mason University Libraries.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Michael La Vean French documents collection, C0078, Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University Libraries.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Collection donated by Michael La Vean in 2004.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Special Collections and Archives staff. EAD markup completed by Eron Ackerman and Jordan Patty in March 2009.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Michael La Vean is an entrepreneur and medical device patent holder who studied Business Administration at George Mason University. He spent seven years in Rennes, France, and collects books and documents, especially those relevant to politics and the history of women in eighteenth and nineteenth century France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The La Vean collection contains 268 documents and books from the period between 1751 and 1851. It includes copies of legislation by the French constitutional monarchy and the evolving Republic; administrative correspondence and official records from Morbihan; a few London newspapers mentioning France; ten books, notably a 1797 edition of Three Memorials on French Affairs by Sir Edmund Burke; and other materials. The majority of the documents come from the years between the creation of the French National Assembly in 1789 and the beginning of the Empire in 1805.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Special Collections and Archives also holds the La Vean Collection that consists of multiple volumes on the French Revolution donated by Michael La Vean. The books can be found by searching for "La Vean Collection" in the .
